urn:contentItem:5SR9-WB41-F0JP-W2DX-00000-00Samuel to regulators: 'Stick to your brief'2018-07-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 28Samuel to regulators: 'Stick to your brief'Ticky Fullerton EXCLUSIVE

The former ACCC boss warns of the challenges they face

A decade after the financial -crisis, a royal commission into -financial misconduct and the public and politicians are demanding retribution. There are shifting sands for any regulator.

The big three - ASIC, APRA and the ACCC - are all in various ways under scrutiny.

"It may well be that the regulators have to have a hard look at themselves," explains one of the country's most experienced former regulators, Graeme Samuel. He points to the Capability -Review of ASIC chaired by Karen Chester from 2015.

"She was focusing a lot on the remit of ASIC - the expectation gaps that were there - and she had some quite interesting comments to make about the governance, many of which were rejected by Greg Medcraft. But I was reading her report just the other day and I thought there's a lot of very interesting stuff there that frankly all regulators ought to have a bit of a look at and examine, and say should it perhaps apply to them?" Samuel has never liked- -monopolies and never much liked market dominance. In his most -influential position, eight years as the chair of the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission until 2011, Samuel pursued and successfully prosecuted Australia's most famous cartel case against Richard Pratt's Visy Corporation. As a businessman in the 1980s, he bust open the stockbrokers fixed commissions. As the former head of the National Competition Council, he drove reforms for the national electricity market. As an AFL commissioner, he pushed for a national competition.

He was one of a three-member panel that recently delivered the damning review into the Commonwealth Bank. That review - which is now being passed around all of the boardrooms of Australia's biggest listed companies - should not be regarded a new blueprint for corporate governance, he insists. "No. No, it's not a new benchmark. All it's doing is saying that this is the way that the panel thought proper corporate governance ought to operate and we found failings in the CBA at all levels." Samuel's latest role is in chairing Airlines for Australia and New Zealand, an airline lobby group determined to expose the gouging by airports both in the air and on land.

But right now, we sit down for a free-flowing talk on regulators,- -including the challenges facing Rod Sims with his controversial banking cartel case and judge Kenneth Hayne with the banking royal commission.

Many times Graeme Samuel comes back to the fundamental rules for the regulator, appointed under statute and the importance of sticking to the brief. And he calls out three "really interesting diversions" that can and do occur.

"Number one: where the chair or the CEO gets drawn into the process of self-promotion" he -explains. "That so often happens when you get involved in international conferences, international organisations and the like. I know when I first started at the ACCC I was encouraged to get involved in these, particularly by my predecessor Alan Fels. I went to one meeting overseas and I thought this is a total waste of time for the ACCC! Yes, it might be good for me in terms of promotion, of profile on an international stage; you can feel good about that. But meanwhile there's activity occurring in Australia that really has to be dealt with." Does this mean it's not a good idea for ASIC chair Greg Medcraft to be on the board of the International Organisation of Securities Commissions, spending chunks of time overseas?

"It certainly diverts the attention of the chairman from the fundamental responsibility that is carrying out your responsibilities under the legislation. I'm wary of the relevance of doing those international type roles, particularly when you take on the head of IOSCO for example wary about the burden, the time commitment and the time it takes you from carrying out responsibilities under the legislation.

"The second diversion," Samuel continues enthusiastically "is that you get drawn into what I call the policy-making areas. Regulators love to be policymakers, they love to be thinking they're going to save the world and change policy. That's not their remit. That's why I've always been cautious about the conduct by regulators of market studies or market analysis." Wait a minute. Isn't the regulator in the perfect position to do work in this area? What about the landmark review that ACCC chairman Rod Sims is doing into digital platforms?

"Frankly, I would have thought that was more appropriate to be dealt with by the Productivity Commission," Samuel says.

"I noticed that Rod was quoted the other day as saying that this particular review is 'a lot of fun'. It's actually not a lot of fun, it a -serious issue and when you make a statement - and look it might have been a slip on his part - but when you make a statement that it's 'a lot of fun', it suggests that you're being diverted into areas that you really can get some fun and excitement out of when the real issue is enforcement of the law." I push again: surely, the digital platform review is a market competition issue? The ad revenue of traditional media is being hollowed out by Big Tech.

"Of course the PC is well versed in competition issues, its fundamental economic philosophy is that of encouraging competition," Samuel says. "Stephen King is one of its commissioners, he's a former member of the ACCC, probably Australia's best known and best organised -industrial organisation economist. They've got a lot of skills to be able to deal with those things and they do so in an environment where their remit is to look at policy. They seek and obtain submissions from ACCC, ASIC all other parties that might be relevant." At this point, my thoughts flash to an old rule in television: never say at the start I have three points to make. There are so many reasons why you might not finish the list. Not so here, however. "Number three is the really significant one: a regulator, and particularly those that have to enforce the law, cannot feel the need to be liked. Now let me say industry is very adept at what I'll call industry capture, at getting regulators as part of their network. And they do it with lunches and dinners and inviting you to sporting events and the like - something I used to -resist an enormous amount -because it gave me the sense that what they were trying to do was to become so close to you, so friendly that you felt a constraint when it came to enforcing the law.

"You cannot feel the need to be liked unless you want to sacrifice your primary remit - to act in the public interest. So sometimes you lose friends as a result. You lose -associations. You're seen as being a bit distant. But ultimately, that's the role of the regulator." 'I've lost some friends' Graeme Samuel has lost friends over his career. There was the spectacular falling out with Chris Corrigan, with whom he busted the broker commissions, only to later call for more competition at the ports where Corrigan was king. But the decisions that cost him most personally, and indeed divided the Melbourne Jewish community, was his pursuit of Richard Pratt in the cartel case against Visy. No one can deny that here, Samuel walked the walk.

"There is no question that the whole Pratt/Visy exercise was personally very trying. I had significant representations from some people in the Melbourne community who said to me, 'Graeme, this is not the way we deal with these things. Can we fix this up? Can we mediate? And I said no you can't. This is a serious issue -involving cartel conduct. It will go before the courts and that's exactly what we did. And the court vindicated our approach. Yes, I lost some friends. I've still lost some, people that don't talk to me now." The low point for Samuel would surely be where his own business dealings were in question, where he had to defend the blind trust structure for his investments, one of which, a fashion business, went to the wall. "The greatest complexity was that when those challenges arose, -people were using the media to try and put be under pressure and that's really difficult when you're in public office." As for penalties versus enforceable undertakings, Samuel sees value in both but that the more frequent use of criminal prosecutions will be far more important. "I'll never forget getting the $37m cheque from Visy in respect of the cartel verdict from Justice Peter Heerey. I looked at the cheque and I've actually still got a photocopy at home, and it was signed by the finance director of Visy and I'm thinking, it doesn't really matter to Visy. What was really important was the publicity that occurred." Samuel has cited the strong language in the Heerey verdict and the crucial role played by the Victorian DPP that led to criminal charges against an ailing Richard Pratt, charges which were eventually quashed.

What then, does Samuel make of the current criminal charges against bankers, individuals as a result of Sims' ACCC cartel case against ANZ, Citigroup and Deutsche? And does he believe that ASIC and APRA will be brave enough also to bring more criminal action in future?

"It has a massive impact on the market and the reverberations are being felt at the moment. You can imagine that there will be an enormous degree of caution about what is done in this area into the future. My understanding is that there has already been discussion between ASIC and the industry about this sort of behaviour, although it postdated the subject of this particular prosecution. But that discussion has been taking place and ASIC and ACCC has been talking to industry and saying, look, this can't continue, it has to change. We know ASIC is looking at this issue of disclosure.

"My initiation reaction was a bit of a query because when you enter into joint underwritings there's no competition. And so therefore you can't have a cartel. But there's a point with joint underwritings, particularly once the issue has taken place where the joint arrangement if you like, ceases, when you have to deal with the shortfall. And then you might get into an issue of competition and potential collusiveness because that occurs there." Particularly when a retail deal comes straight after that placement one might ponder. Like the rest of us, Samuel waits to see just how the court will deal with this. But he stresses that while the ACCC is bringing on the case, no criminal prosecution can take place unless the DPP is satisfied both of reasonable grounds for success and that the prosecution is in the public interest.

"Well, apparently the Commonwealth DPP is," I say. "Well that's the point," he retorts.

Samuel's perspective on Kenneth Hayne and his royal commission is insightful. "You got to remember: what we are going through is a series of eight â€¦ I'll call them show trials. Eight theatres. Ken Hayne actually got all the information he needed at the very early stages, -because he asked for 50-page confessions from every organisation. And they had to confess, so he knows what has gone wrong, he knows all those issues. Now we're going through a series of two-weekly show trials. And they're good, except," he stresses "except that they can raise expectations too high. So the first couple of show trials, AMP and one about CBA and credit card insurance, had people horrified that this was going on: a chair lost her role, some directors had to resign from AMP. Now what that does is, it says to the public at large there's a lot of horrific things happening."Ticky Fullerton presents Ticky at 5.30pm weeknights on Sky News Business.

urn:contentItem:606D-TJG1-JCJY-G264-00000-00Sanctions for directors could be part of duty of care penalties, Ofcom chief says2020-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1Sanctions for directors could be part of duty of care penalties, Ofcom chief saysBy Mike Wright , Social Media Correspondent

Ofcom's chief executive has warned tech giants could face "sanctions for directors" if the watchdog is appointed to oversee Duty of Care legislation.

Dame Melanie Dawes said that large fines "needed to be part" of the new online regulatory regime being drawn up by the Government.

Her comments come as ministers are considering what powers to arm the new regulator with when they impose a statutory duty of care on tech companies, as measure The Telegraph has been campaigning for since 2018.

Current proposals could see a regulator being able to levy fines running into the billions of pounds on companies that fail to protect children and other users from harm.

Other sanctions under consideration are fines or criminal prosecution for directors of failing companies as well as powers to block online and social media companies in the UK if they repeatedly breach their duty of care.

Earlier this year, the Government said it is 'minded' to make Ofcom the new online regulator and the decision is expected to be confirmed later this year.

Appearing before MPs on the culture select committee yesterday, Dame Dawes that Ofcom could use existing penalties such as a "disruption of service temporarily" against sites who fail to protect users.

The new head of Ofcom, who took up the role in March, said she had been alarmed by the spread of fake coronavirus news on social media sites during the lockdown, such as conspiracy theories that 5G mobile signal spread the virus.

She said: "We need to know a lot more about the behaviour of anonymous accounts. Transparency at the moment is just not good enough."

Dame Dawes highlighted a David Icke interview which was broadcast on local TV station London Live, where the conspiracy theorist shared his unsubstantiated views on the causes behind the outbreak of Covid-19.

She said that while Ofcom had been able to take action against the broadcaster over the incident, videos of the interview were still able to spread on platforms such as YouTube, although she did acknowledge that YouTube had moved to take them down.

Following, Dame Dawes's appearance, the NSPCC warned the ministers had to give the new duty of care regulator credible sanctions to ensure the tech giants didn't see it as a 'paper tiger'.

Andy Burrows, Head of Child Safety Online Policy at the NSPCC, said: "Unless Ofcom are given the teeth to hit companies hard in the pocket and commit to a named director scheme with criminal sanctions, the Online Harms Bill could risk becoming a paper tiger.

"This needs to be backed up by a corporate criminal offence for gross breaches of a company's duty of care to children, while super complaints should be used to hold big tech to account for systemic failings."

urn:contentItem:5TVK-Y6V1-DXY4-X1GV-00000-00Sandberg Asked Staff To Research Soros Links2018-11-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 1Sandberg Asked Staff To Research Soros LinksBy NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and MATTHEW ROSENBERG; Reporting was contributed by Sheera Frenkel, Jack Nicas, Cecilia Kang and Mike Isaac.

Follow Nicholas Confessore and Matthew Rosenberg on Twitter: @nickconfessore @AllMattNYT

Sheryl Sandberg asked Facebook's communications staff to research George Soros's financial interests in the wake of his high-profile attacks on tech companies, according to three people with knowledge of her request, indicating that Facebook's second in command was directly involved in the social network's response to the liberal billionaire.

Ms. Sandberg, Facebook's chief operating officer, asked for the information in an email to a senior executive in January that was forwarded to other senior communications and policy staff, the people said. The email came within days of a blistering speech Mr. Soros delivered that month at the World Economic Forum, attacking Facebook and Google as a ''menace'' to society and calling for the companies to be regulated.

Ms. Sandberg -- who was at the forum, but was not present for Mr. Soros's speech, according to a person who attended it -- requested an examination into why Mr. Soros had criticized the tech companies and whether he stood to gain financially from the attacks. At the time, Facebook was under growing scrutiny for the role its platform had played in disseminating Russian propaganda and fomenting campaigns of hatred in Myanmar and other countries.

Facebook later commissioned a campaign-style opposition research effort by Definers Public Affairs, a Republican-linked firm, which gathered and circulated to reporters public information about Mr. Soros's funding of American advocacy groups critical of Facebook.

Those efforts, revealed this month in a New York Times investigation, set off a public relations debacle for Ms. Sandberg and for Facebook, which was accused of trafficking in anti-Semitic attacks against the billionaire. Facebook quickly fired Definers.

The people with knowledge of Ms. Sandberg's email asked for anonymity because they weren't authorized to discuss the message and feared retribution.

In a statement, Facebook said that the company had already begun researching Mr. Soros when Ms. Sandberg made her request.

''Mr. Soros is a prominent investor and we looked into his investments and trading activity related to Facebook,'' the company said. ''That research was already underway when Sheryl sent an email asking if Mr. Soros had shorted Facebook's stock.'' The company said that while Ms. Sandberg ''takes full responsibility for any activity that happened on her watch,'' she did not personally direct any research on Freedom from Facebook, an anti-Facebook coalition whose members were among the subjects of Definers' later work.

Eddie Vale, a spokesman for Freedom from Facebook, said he was skeptical of the company's account.

''In light of Sandberg's continuously changing story on the Soros research, there's no way their denials about attacking other critics can be taken at face value,'' Mr. Vale said. ''Facebook must immediately release any emails and any research about targeting the Freedom from Facebook coalition or any member organizations.''

The revelation complicates Ms. Sandberg's shifting explanations of her role in Facebook's decisions to hire Definers and go on the offensive against the social network's growing legion of critics. Ms. Sandberg at first denied knowing that Facebook had hired Definers, before acknowledging in a post last week that some of the company's work for Facebook had crossed her desk.

In that post, Ms. Sandberg did not explicitly deny that she had asked for research into Mr. Soros. Instead, a deputy who oversaw the communications team but is now leaving the company, Elliot J. Schrage, took responsibility for hiring Definers and initiating Definers' investigation into Mr. Soros. It is unclear what, if any, involvement Ms. Sandberg had in that ultimate response to Mr. Soros.

''We had not heard such criticism from him before and wanted to determine if he had any financial motivation,'' Mr. Schrage said of Mr. Soros. ''Definers researched this using public information.''

Facebook has defended its inquiries into Mr. Soros as a prudent and necessary step for any public company under attack by a high-profile figure -- particularly one like Mr. Soros, a onetime currency trader who made a fortune in the 1990s betting against the British pound.

But the revelations are likely to escalate pressure on Ms. Sandberg, an embattled Silicon Valley star and feminist author.

The Times investigation found that Ms. Sandberg and Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, had ignored warnings about abuse on the platform and sought to conceal from public view evidence that Russia had used it to disrupt the 2016 presidential campaign and help elect President Trump. The Times also found that when Facebook was confronted last spring with revelations that the privacy of tens of millions of users had been compromised by Cambridge Analytica, a Trump-linked data firm, Ms. Sandberg and Mr. Zuckerberg sought to downplay the problem and deflect blame.

But it is Ms. Sandberg who oversees Facebook's policy and communications arms, which starting last year embarked on a hard-edged lobbying campaign to discredit the company's critics and push back on the growing chorus of voices calling for Facebook and other big tech companies to be broken up or more tightly regulated.

Some have called on Ms. Sandberg to be fired. Last week's admission by Mr. Schrage -- a Sandberg confidante who announced in June that he was leaving the company -- was widely viewed inside and outside the company as an effort to insulate her from damage.

Facebook hired Definers last year to monitor media coverage and then expanded its role to include campaign-style research and other public relations work.

In a private meeting on Thursday, Ms. Sandberg again distanced herself from Definers and its research into Mr. Soros, according to Rashad Robinson, head of the racial-justice group Color of Change, which was named in a Definers memo about Mr. Soros.

Mr. Robinson said that while meeting with Ms. Sandberg, she denied hiring Definers or directing the firm's research.

''She very much placed it on the now departed communications chief'' -- Mr. Schrage -- ''and also worked to assure us that Joel Kaplan had nothing to do with it either,'' Mr. Robinson said. Mr. Kaplan is the company's vice president of global public policy.

Mr. Robinson said he was pleased Ms. Sandberg had agreed to release a progress report on a previously announced internal audit into how Facebook's policies affected minority users and employees. But when he pushed for more on Facebook's involvement with Definers, Mr. Robinson said, Ms. Sandberg kept stressing that Facebook had fired the firm.

''We were not satisfied with that answer,'' he said.

urn:contentItem:5Y9X-MDR1-F0J6-J38J-00000-00SANDERS UNNERVES INVESTORS2020-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 44SANDERS UNNERVES INVESTORSJacob Greber

US election Trump dubs him a dangerous socialist, but what if Sanders gets elected, asks AFR Washington correspondent Jacob Greber.

Between the coronavirus, sluggish economic growth, tapped-out monetary policy, deficit-driven economic growth and a president shaking the foundations of the global trading system, it's not like Americans didn't already have enough to worry about.

Now here comes Bernie Sanders, the independent democratic socialist whose promises of "political revolution" and a slug to the wealthy to fund healthcare and education for all have turned him into the front-runner among Democrats vying to become president.

While US sharemarkets have for days and weeks seemingly ignored the threats from viruses and policy-driven asset bubbles - sending the stock indices to ever higher records - the spell appears to be broken.

So far this week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has shed more than 1900 points in two days - or more than 5 per cent - its biggest decline in more than two years.

Analysts believe at least some of the drop was caused by the Vermont senator's big win in Nevada on Saturday, which adds to his first place in the New Hampshire primary earlier this month.

"You have a lot of things that are overhanging on the economy and now you have the introduction of the idea that Bernie Sanders might be the nominee for the Democrats," said Anthony Scaramucci, a Wall Street money manager who once worked as Donald Trump's White House press secretary and has since vowed to campaign against the President in the lead-up to November.

Scaramucci believes the odds of a Sanders victory against Donald Trump in November are already at 45 to 48 per cent.

"There has to be a probability that [Trump] doesn't beat him," he told The Australian Financial Review. "So once Bernie Sanders is named the nominee, you know there has to be a correction [in markets]."

The sudden resurrection of Sanders ahead of more conventional moderate alternatives, such as former vice-president Joe Biden and former Republican and former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg, is forcing Wall Street to revisit what the independent senator's presidency would mean in practice.

Active in office since 1981 when he became mayor of the New England town of Burlington in Vermont, Sanders has for most of his public career been dismissed as an obscure and slightly laughable left-wing figure. He famously took his wife on a honeymoon to the Soviet Union in 1988 and set up sister-city programs with places such as Puerta Cabezas in Nicaragua and Yaroslavl in Russia.

In short, the bearded lady of American politics.

But nobody is dismissing him now.

Over the past decade, Sanders - who joined the Senate in 2007 after 16 years in the House of Representatives - has watched and benefited as a large slab of the Democrat base shifted in his direction.

Having narrowly lost the 2016 Democratic nomination to Hillary Clinton, Sanders relaunched his bid for the presidency early last year and has stood out as the party's most organised and prolific fundraiser ever since.

Ideologically, Sanders says his way of seeing the world is no longer on the fringes and argues that his model for America isn't anything people in Scandinavia or many other parts of Europe would regard as radical.

"Ideas that seemed radical four years ago are now kind of mainstream," he told the 60 Minutes on Sunday - the day after his thumping victory in the Nevada caucus.

The speed of that shift is coming as a shock to many on Wall Street, not the least because Sanders is riding a wave of grassroots fervour among mostly young voters who are buying into the senator's plans for an all-out assault on corporate America and its hard-charging model of capitalism.

As president, Sanders would reverse Trump's corporate tax cuts, returning the headline rate back up to its pre-2017 rate of 35 per cent, from 21 per cent, and lift the federal minimum wage to $US15 ($22.73) an hour.

Consistent with his campaign attacks on the "billionaire class", Sanders wants to introduce an "extreme wealth tax" on top-earning Americans alongside a national "wealth registry" to prevent tax avoidance.

Those with net worth north of $US32 million would pay 1 per cent, rising to a maximum of 8 per cent on wealth of more than $US$10 billion.

Sanders also wants to halt capital gains breaks for households with incomes above $US250,000, and believes there should be a tax on all Wall Street financial transactions.

Next would likely be what could become the largest trust-busting campaign in a century, targeting for a break-up of too-big-to-fail banks and big tech firms that together account for about a quarter of the S&P's market value. His boldest promise by far would be the creation of a national healthcare scheme that would do away with private insurance that currently covers around 160 million Americans.

In its place would be a universal system that he says would cost less while extending coverage to more than 30 million people outside the system.

He has flagged a system in which workers with a family of four earning more than $US29,000 would pay a 4 per cent family premium on every dollar earned above that level.

It would save the average family paying private insurance $US4775 a year.

Employers would shift away from private premiums, which cost on average $US14,561 for a worker with a family of four, to a single 7.5 per cent payroll tax at a cost of $US4500.

Still, introducing "Medicare for all" would lift federal spending over the first decade by between $US32 trillion and $US34 trillion, according to calculations released by the Urban Institute, a centre-left think tank in Washington.

That number is greater than the American government's total cost over the same period for social security, Medicare and Medicaid - the nation's largest entitlement programs - according to Congressional Budget Office projections.

Another major Sanders proposal is to cancel all college debt and make public colleges, universities and trade schools tuition free, which his campaign has costed at $US2.2 trillion over 10 years.

Then there are big-spending plans to provide "housing for all" ($US2.5 trillion over a decade) and universal childcare ($US1.5 trillion). Even if a hostile congress blocks much of the Sanders agenda, Trump's liberal use of executive orders has created a precedent for wide-ranging intervention across the economy.

Sanders has promised to introduce government regulations to curb emissions. He wants to ban fracking and supports shuttering existing nuclear power reactors and slash $US1.22 trillion from defence spending.

While his weekend Nevada caucus win triggered a sharp sell-off across US healthcare stocks, some analysts have argued that his plans could actually spur economic growth, at least for a time.

Plans for removing the burden of repaying university debt and providing a single-payer healthcare system could free up household resources for new spending and investment. Sanders also backs infrastructure investment and has expressed approval for a "Green New Deal" splurge on high-speed rail, electric transport and more public options to cut emissions.

"Wall Street's getting nervous, the insurance industry's getting nervous, drug companies are getting nervous, and the Democratic establishment is getting nervous," Sanders reportedly told supporters in recent days.

Scaramucci suggests the Sanders resurgence is linked to deteriorating income inequality caused by the same interest rate cuts Trump has so vociferously demanded of the US Federal Reserve.

"The great irony of the interest rate activity and the co-ordination of the Federal Reserve with the global banks is that it's having a very big effect on populism, the spectre of nationalism and all this other stuff," he told The Australian Financial Review. "The rich have gotten way richer. "

The result is a pending battle between a "radical, oligarchic right-wing figure in Donald Trump, that's going to be going up against a first-time, self-declared American socialist".

"I would tell you right now: don't underestimate the passion and the angry disaffected people who feel disadvantaged by the elites and the establishment that could potentially side with a guy like Bernie Sanders," Scaramucci said.

So far, Trump appears to relish the idea of a Sanders nomination, applauding the senator's Nevada win and urging him to fight against the Democratic Party machine's desire to install a moderate.

Clearly, it's because many Republicans believe Sanders will be an easy beat once they've pilloried him as a dangerous socialist radical desperate to impose a Venezuelan hell-scape on the American people.

While there's every chance that strategy will work for Trump come November, there's a risk for the President that just enough Americans in the key swing states might go for the Sanders plan, assuming he gets the nomination.

Sanders is no Jeremy Corbyn, the failed British Labour leader whose plan included genuine socialism, such as the nationalisation of railways, electricity distribution, the post office, and water utilities.

But he still seems radical by conventional American standards. If that's still a thing. AFR

urn:contentItem:5X9X-7T51-JBSN-1009-00000-00Sanders Would Unravel Trump Administration Approved Mergers2019-10-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisSanders Would Unravel Trump Administration Approved Mergersby David Hatch

A Bernie Sanders presidency would make seismic changes to antitrust, including a sweeping overhaul of the Federal Trade Commission and thorough reviews of Trump administration-approved mergers with an eye toward unwinding monopolies and anticompetitive combinations.

In a newly released https://berniesanders.com/issues/corporate-accountability-and-democracy/ |blueprint on corporate accountability, the Democratic presidential candidate was harsh in his criticism of the five-member commission, now comprised of three Republicans and two Democrats.

The Federal Trade Commission has failed its mission, the Vermont Independent wrote in his plan, released in advance of the Tuesday, Oct. 15, Democratic presidential debate in Ohio. The senator envisioned new enforcement powers that would enable the FTC to block mergers without legal challenges and impose steeper financial penalties.

The proposals come amid a Trump administration crackdown in Washington on Silicon Valley icons. The FTC and Department of Justice have launched multiple investigations into alleged anticompetitive behavior as they explore whether acquisitions of promising startups should be blocked.

Sanders' recommendations follow threats by Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., the leading Democratic contender, to https://medium.com/@teamwarren/heres-how-we-can-break-up-big-tech-9ad9e0da324c |break up Facebook, Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) and Google by treating them as platform utilities subject to strict government regulation. House Democrats are conducting a series of hearings on the market power of major internet companies.

Even if the 78-year-old senator doesn t become the Democratic nominee, some of his policy priorities could be reflected in the https://democrats.org/where-we-stand/party-platform/ |party platform, to be updated for the 2020 Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee next July.

Under the Trump administration, the FTC has shown deference to the largest, most powerful corporations instead of fighting for workers and consumers, Sanders lamented in his plan.

Describing a https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/blogs/business-blog/2019/07/ftcs-5-billion-facebook-settlement-record-breaking-history|$5 billion FTC settlement with Facebook, Inc. (FB) as a slap on the wrist and a   https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2019/09/google-youtube-will-pay-record-170-million-alleged-violations|$170 million settlement with Alphabet Inc.'s (GOOGL) YouTube LLC for privacy violations involving children as too lenient, the senator asserted that the FTC has lost its credibility as a regulatory agency.

The FTC characterized both fines as record-breaking.

Some proposals would require tremendous resources to implement and may be impractical for an agency that routinely complains it needs more funding and personnel.

For example, the FTC would be instructed to evaluate all mergers and acquisitions over the past 40 years to set up new guidelines for approval that will have a special focus on economic security, job security, and competition.

Such an extraordinary feat likely would require the participation of the DOJ antitrust division, never mentioned in the blueprint, and other federal agencies that participate in merger reviews. Basing antitrust analysis on economic and job security also likely would require congressional action.

urn:contentItem:5SBC-5S91-F03R-N4PB-00000-00San Francisco is fed up with Big Tech, and residents are begging the next mayor to do something about it2018-05-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisSan Francisco is fed up with Big Tech, and residents are begging the next mayor to do something about itMelia Robinson

May 15, 2018( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) San Francisco's out-of-control housing prices continues to cause an uproar. With the election for San Francisco mayor less than three weeks away, many residents are focused on how the candidates will fix the housing crisis. For some candidates, that means asking the tech industry to answer for gentrification and the impact it's had on the real estate market. San Francisco is in trouble.

The streets[1] are filthy. Housing prices are out-of-control. The city is host to 1.23% ofallhomeless Americans[2]. Some San Franciscans are fed up with the tech industry, which they blame for gentrification and the still-painful housing crisis. They want a reckoning to come for Big Tech — courtesy of the next mayor. San Francisco elects a new mayor in less than three weeks, and the candidates are battling over the best path to regulate the tech industry and its presence in the city. The top contenders are expected to take a harder line with the tech companies that have sprouted throughout the city, thanks to generous tax breaks and other favorable policies. The era of tech-friendly civic policy in San Francisco may be coming to an end. Seven mayoral candidates met for one final debate on Monday evening at the Commonwealth Club. During the last portion of the debate, the moderator read questions from the audience, ranging in topic from the city's homelessness[3] epidemic to the onslaught of electric scooters[4]. "Why is the rent so damn high[5]?" the moderator read from a card. The room broke out in laughter that quickly subsided, as an audience of about 200 people waited to hear how their next mayor plans to reckon with out-of-control housing prices. San Francisco is in the thralls of a housing emergency. The median two-bedroom rent[6] of $3,060 is more than double the national average of $1,170, and only 12%[7] of families can afford to buy a home in the city. Lower-income residents[8] are leaving in droves, as tech and finance professionals migrate into the city for high-paying jobs, driving housing prices even higher. Audience questions during the debate made it clear, if it weren't before: Some residents are fed up with what they see as the tech industry leeching off their city, and they want the next mayor to force Big Tech to pay up. Candidate Mark Leno, a former California state senator, called on tech companies to hire more residents for jobs in administrative offices and sales. He cited the number of college-educated San Franciscans driving taxis to suggest that underemployment is something tech can solve. "We need to make sure that [the tech industry's] success is our success," Leno said.Supervisor Jane Kim, who's also running for mayor, came down on the tech industry for "their role in exacerbating the income gap," which she called the fastest-growing[9] in the country. San Francisco's middle class shrank from about half the population[10] in the 1990s to about 33%[11] in 2012. She suggested that local government work together with the tech industry to address how these companies "treat their lowest-paid workers." She asked, "What benefits do they provide them?" Kim went on, "Can they stop contracting out [...] so that our janitors, our cafeteria workers, our security guards have security to live in the Bay Area and be able to raise their families here?" Candidate Ellen Lee Zhou, a public health worker and union representative considered to be an underdog, asked that the tech industry considered "supplying their own apartments for their own employees." As mayor, she said she would ask tech companies to donate buildings for developing affordable housing. People from the audience asked the candidates to address the insane traffic jams that residents face downtown, where some6,500 Uber and Lyft cars[12] roam the streets during peak hours. Richie Greenberg, a small business adviser and the only Republican in the race, and San Francisco Board of Supervisors President London Breed — who served as acting mayor briefly after the sudden death of previous mayor Ed Lee — both said they would place a cap on the number of ride-hailing cars permitted on the road at any time. Breed went a step further, saying she would curb some vehicles with on-demand startups like Postmates and Caviar to reduce congestion. San Francisco will vote on June 5 — the same day as the statewide California elections. urn:contentItem:5R71-M721-JCMN-Y346-00000-00San Francisco is getting a new mayor after Ed Lee's death, and the tech industry's cozy status in the city may be finished2017-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisSan Francisco is getting a new mayor after Ed Lee's death, and the tech industry's cozy status in the city may be finishedZoë Bernard

Dec 19, 2017( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Facebook/supervisorlondonbreed San Francisco mayor Edwin Lee died last week, leaving behind a seven year legacy in city politics. Lee is considered largely responsible for bolstering the city's economy by ushering in the post-recession tech boom. Lee faced past controversy regarding San Francisco's increased gentrification and punishing housing market. With his passing, it's possible that city candidates might take a tougher stance on the tech industry.  The tech industry's cozy status as San Francisco's most favored group could be on its way out as a new group of politicians jockey for the vacant mayor's seat following the sudden death of Ed Lee last week. [1] Two of the top contenders for the job, Acting Mayor London Breed and former State Senator Mark Leno, are both expected to take a tougher line with the tech firms that have sprouted throughout the city thanks to generous tax breaks and other favorable policies.

Although none of the major contenders for the mayor's job have been outright antagonistic towards tech, they've shown a willingness to be less accommodating than Lee. And with the city's housing crisis throbbing, and ongoing debate about the effect of gentrification and "tech bros" on San Francisco's infrastructure, affordability and culture, the days of hands-off treatment for tech may be coming to an end. "What you'll see is a less friendly environment, more scrutiny, and possibly less of an appetite for a tax break ever again," a longtime San Francisco political consultant told Business Insider. "As these companies mature, and as the city matures, the policy discussions are going to become a little less one-sided, and a little bit more about what the companies need to do in order to behave," the consultant, who declined to be identified, added.  A special election to choose the new mayor will take place in June 2018. Until then the city's board of supervisors must agree on an interim Mayor to serve as a caretaker.  Breed, until recently the president of the city's board of supervisors, is viewed as one of the favorites for the June election, although she has yet to official declare her intention to run.  A 43-year old San Francisco native who grew up in public housing, Breed has turned critical eye on the city's tech industry in the past — a stance which put her at political odds with Mayor Lee. Last year, she co-sponsored a bill[2] which proposed a strict 60-day-per-year limit on short-term rentals in a direct response to Airbnb's largely unregulated influence on the city's housing and hotel markets. Lee vetoed the bill, saying that it would only drive more homeowners to rent their properties illegally. In 2016, Breed centered her supervisor re-election campaign on building and protecting affordable housing, a crucial issue in a city where the median cost of rent has soared to $4,450 a month[3]. The city's punishing housing market is considered a direct result of the influx of high-wage earning tech workers, and Breed has described [4]her resolve to fight towards tenants rights as a "personal matter." It's a stance that could cause tension with big tech, which until now has comfortably sprawled throughout the downtown districts, both commercially[5] and residentially[6]. "Your success has also created tension"That's not to say that Breed is inherently opposed to tech or unwilling to collaborate with the industry. Appearing at the 2015 "Crunchies" awards organized by tech blog TechCrunch[7], Breed said she had "great respect for the tech sector, for the dreamers and entrepreneurs who want to create something new, something innovative." But, she added, "right or wrong, your success has also created tension."  "It's time for us to work together and make sure every San Franciscan shares in the prosperity," she said. The race to replace Lee, who died on Tuesday after seven years in office as San Francisco's mayor, comes as San Francisco struggles to adapt to the rapid changes bought by the tech industry. Only last week, the board unanimously approved stringent regulations on delivery robots that ride on city sidewalks[8].  Lee oversaw San Francisco through a time of severe economic upheaval following the recession [9]and played an integral role in fostering San Francisco's developing tech industry. During his time as mayor, he provided generous tax incentives to tech companies[10], held close relationships with prominent venture capitalists[11], and took an active interest in nurturing the city's burgeoning start-up scene[12].  Mark Leno, who had already declared his intention to run for Mayor after Lee's term expired[13], has been critical of Lee's accommodating stance toward tech. 'As mayor, I'll fight on behalf of regular San Franciscans — immigrants, tenants, homeowners and small businesses. I promise to give a voice to every resident of our city — especially to those who feel marginalized or left behind," he told the LA Times in May.[14] Like Breed, Leno is focused on the city's housing market, spearheading a bill protecting tenants rights in 2015[15]. And he has approved of tighter tech regulations in the past. In 2014, Leno authored the smart phone "kill switch bill" which called for antitheft security features [16]to be included in smartphones.  Leno and Breed did not return requests for comment on their views about tech. Tech 'hasn't paid its fair share' While tech figures, such as investor Ron Conway, were big supporters of Lee's, the mayor's stance towards the tech industry was criticized by many city residents. In November, the San Francisco Chronicle reported that Lee's approval ratings had sunk [17]to just 30 percent. "The tech industry hasn't paid its fair share and has contributed to the displacement of low-income communities, seniors and our most vulnerable," Gilbert Williams, a member of the grassroots activist group Alliance of Californians for Community Empowerment told Business Insider in an email.  "We would hope the new mayor took the tech industry's enormous wealth, and used it to help create a permanent anti-displacement fund that includes immediate solutions for renters and homeowners," he said.NOW WATCH: How Area 51 became the center of alien conspiracy theories[18]See Also: I've worked urn:contentItem:5WVX-S291-DXH2-62HF-00000-00San Francisco Problems?; Labor Day Travel; Judge Orders Further Investigation Into Christopher Steele Documents; Tech Giant Antitrust Investigation; Joe Biden Increases Lead In Polls; President Trump Comments On Economy2019-08-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTMark Murphy, Robert Patillo, Emily Larsen, Leeza Garber, Doug Burns, Ned Ryun, Danielle DiMartino Booth, Scott Martin, Lee MunsonNEWSDomestic082001cb.140San Francisco Problems?; Labor Day Travel; Judge Orders Further Investigation Into Christopher Steele Documents; Tech Giant Antitrust Investigation; Joe Biden Increases Lead In Polls; President Trump Comments On EconomyMaria Bartiromo, John Roberts, Karl Rove, Peter Doocy, Lisa Kennedy Montgomery, Claudia Cowan

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Well, amid signs the global economy is slowing, the president is now talking about cutting taxes.

Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Payroll tax is something that we think about. And a lot of people would like to see. And that very much affects the working -- the workers of our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump also taking aim at the Federal Reserve, saying that they have been tardy when it comes to cutting interest rates. He's calling for a full percent cut, maybe not all at once, but over time.

Not helping stocks today. Market closing at the lows right now, down 170 points on the Dow industrials.

Welcome, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo, in today for Neil Cavuto. This is YOUR WORLD.

John Roberts at the White House right now, where it all is going down.

John, good afternoon.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good afternoon to you.

President Trump had a lot to talk about today. We were in the Oval Office for about 30 minutes going over a number of different topics. But first and foremost, of course, was where we are with the economy and where we're headed.

There's an old saying that if you talk your -- talk about recession enough, you can talk your way into one. So the president didn't want to talk about recession. He wanted to talk about things that he believes that he might be able to do, and specifically things that the Fed could do to stop us from going into one.

Listen to what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think the word recession is a word that's inappropriate, because it's just a word that the certain people -- I'm going to be kind.

Certain people and the media are trying to build up, because they'd love to see a recession.

We're very far from a recession. In fact, if the Fed would do its job, I think we would have a tremendous spurt of growth, a tremendous spurt.

The Fed is psychologically very important, less so actually, but very psychologically important. And if the Fed would do it's job, which it's really done poorly over the last year-and-a-half, you would see a burst of growth like you have never seen before.

And that would be lowering interest rates.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: The president very critical of Jerome Powell and what the Fed has been doing, believing that they overshot the mark last year, that they raised interest rates too quickly, too fast -- too quickly, too fast, that would be the same thing -- too high, too quickly.

And he doesn't like their program of quantitative tightening. So the president is calling -- called again day in the Oval Office for a cut in the Fed Funds Rate of 100 basis points. That would be a full percentage rate cut, which would take it down to the area of about 1 percent.

The president said, now, not all at once. But then he would also like to see some quantitative easing as well, which we saw during the Obama administration.

Another thing that the president is thinking about, Maria, is indexing capital gains. It's very popular among a lot of people who tend to be wealthy who have a lot of investments in the market, and also considering another potential cut to the payroll tax.

This happened in 2011 and 2012 as part of the economic stimulus in the Obama administration. And that is a tax cut that really affects the middle class, because you cap out at about $95,000. And people who make more than that per year don't get the tax cut. So the tax cut goes to people between about $30,000 and $95,000, which is squarely in the middle class.

Listen to what the president said about that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Payroll taxes, I have been thinking about payroll taxes for a long time. Whether or not we do it now or not is -- it's not being done because of recession, because we are -- legitimately, if we had a cut in interest rates by the Fed, if they would do their job properly, and if they would do a meaningful cut, because they raised too fast, you would see growth like you have not seen ever in this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: You're probably detecting a them there. Even though the president was talking about tax cuts, he came back to the idea of the Fed needing to cut rates and needing to inject some more money into the system as well to keep the economy humming along.

China, Maria, is also a big piece of this. The president again said today that he is not yet ready to cut a deal with China. And he said whether or not there is short-term pain because of his negotiations with China and his policy of tariffs against China to try to bring them to the table is irrelevant.

He says we might need some short-term pain because long term if we don't do something about China, it's going to be catastrophic, because they will eat our lunch five to 10 years from now -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Well, they have said that's where they want to go.

John, thank you so much.

So is a big rate cut and a middle-class tax cut what's needed to keep this economy moving forward?

Let's bring in former Dallas Federal Reserve adviser Danielle DiMartino Booth and market watchers Scott Martin and Lee Munson.

Great to see everybody this morning.

Danielle, let me kick it off with you. Your reaction to a full cut by the Federal Reserve and potentially a cut in payroll taxes?

DANIELLE DIMARTINO BOOTH, FORMER FEDERAL RESERVE ADVISER: Well, it looks like the president is hoping that the country can go out there double- barreled and answer what the European Central Bank, what the Europeans have been promised, which is basically rate cuts and quantitative easing.

He wants to put some fiscal stimulus on top of that that really targets the middle class, and then capital gains tax cuts as well to hold the stock market together. So it really does seem like a perfect Goldilocks scenario, if he was able to wave a magic wand and make this happen overnight.

I don't know how willing Jay Powell and his peers are going to be to launch that type of a shock and awe campaign that was really emblematic of some of the -- some of the crisis years, when the economy was truly in much more than a recession.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Scott Martin, how do you see it?

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Well, it's funny.

I mean, talking about '07, and I remember that fall very well. I got married that fall. And other than that event, it was a really bad fall, because, to Danielle's point, the Fed was cutting rates faster than we could even see them being cut.

And it didn't help. We went into a major financial crisis. And that's what I think worries me here with the Fed on the other side now, as the Trump -- as the president has pointed out, is that they raised too fast. I think they have been too hawkish.

Even when we got the cut recently at the end of July, Maria, says, well, this is a mid-cycle adjustment, don't get used to this, we're not going to be this nice.

So it still -- it still to me boggles my mind that you have the 30-year government bond, my friends a skosh over 2 percent. The Fed Funds' overnight target rate at 2.25 percent, that tells you it's too high.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: They need to listen to the markets, not the president, and cut some more.

BARTIROMO: Yes, look at the 10-year, where that is. I mean, it's just extraordinary, what you're -- what we're looking at here, Lee Munson.

Your reaction. Do you want to see a cut?

LEE MUNSON, PORTFOLIO WEALTH ADVISORS: I want to see a cut. And I will tell you why.

I mean, you ask a lot of bond traders right now, they already think that we're going to see three cuts, maybe 75 basis points, before the end of the year. So the president's not that far off. Number two, I think this is going to be something that's going to help farmers.

I mean, I'm in New Mexico. You go down to Southern New Mexico, and you see land fallow right now. It's going to help drillers in the energy sector that are overleveraged and can use it. And you have also got to look at local regional banks. They need this right now.

What people don't understand Maria is that we have with China intertwined trade and national security issues. I do a lot of business with people in national defense. We have got to deal with this Chinese thing. And the president says he will push this economy into recession to deal with that.

Unlike the Russians, unlike the Soviets, money talks with China, and so I think that we're going to have the guns-and-butter approach. We got to juice this system for the next 12 months so that Trump can get these issues with China worked out.

Again, I'm fiscally conservative, but we have got to address the intellectual property, thievery, the military espionage, Huawei, all that stuff.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

MARTIN: All the things they won't agree on.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: These are all the things that they reneged on.

So -- and, by the way, let's not forget that China has broken its promises so many times in so many different situations, whether it's the WTO, or breaking promises with Hong Kong. Look with the two million people in the streets as we speak. Breaking promises with the U.S., saying that they're going to buy beef, and then they don't.

So even if we were to see a deal, will it be enforceable?

DIMARTINO BOOTH: Well, I think that, Maria, that's fantastic question, because we have seen them renege and go back on their word time and again.

BARTIROMO: Right.

DIMARTINO BOOTH: We have seen the way that they're treating the people in Hong Kong. They're simply not a trustworthy negotiating partner.

And I think that there's every reason to question the integrity of China's intentions at this juncture. What I'm not sure about is whether or not tariffs are the correct instrument anymore. And I think that President Trump has seen that and he pulled back on those September the 1st increased tariffs for that very reason.

And now he's looking for a different way to go about providing relief to this economy, so that it can get through, so that his administration can get through these very tough negotiations.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, the issue is that the economy feels good.

But, at the end of the day, we are seeing a bit of a slowdown. We know that Europe is having a hard time generating any growth.

So what about that, Scott? Do you feel things are poised to slow down considerably by year-end?

MARTIN: I don't know about considerably. I think the slowdown has already begun.

I mean, I think -- you mentioned it. It's overseas. It's definitely in the U.S. The housing market, I know homebuilder sentiment is good, but housing prices, from my eye, in certain areas that have been good have slowed down.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: Home buyer sentiment has kind of cooled off. We have seen business sentiment waver a bit. Consumer sentiment recently fell off some highs.

So I think a slowdown is imminent, if not here already, Maria. But, yes, it's not a major slowdown, but one that needs to be helped along a little bit.

BARTIROMO: Lee Munson, real quick, would you buy into this sell-off or stay on the sidelines here?

MUNSON: Buy in the sell-off. Buy what's beaten up.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MUNSON: We have got 12 more months. And I think the next six months, you buy every dip that you have, and then you start getting concerned. But between now and the end of the year, I think you have to be bold and then - - then I start to get more panicky and freaked out.

BARTIROMO: All right, thank you so much to the panel. Great conversation there.

History says, if the economy is good, there is a good chance that the incumbent president gets four more years. So do some new economic jitters have the White House feeling jittery itself?

We will talk to Karl Rove when we come right back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We heard earlier President Trump saying that some of the media are talking down the economy ahead of the 2020 election.

Want to get that read on the -- on that with the former White House deputy chief of staff for President George W. Bush, Karl Rove.

Karl, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thank you for being here.

KARL ROVE, FORMER SENIOR ADVISER TO PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: And there is something to say about that, that you could talk yourself into a recession, right? How do you see it?

ROVE: Yes, look, it's interesting how the narrative changes.

I mean, we have the economy is going really great, and now doubts about where Europe is or doubts about where the world is suddenly become a tempest of conversation in the media about the recession happening before the 2020 election and this affecting the president's reelection chances.

If a recession were to happen, and it were to happen before the 2020 election, sure kit would have an impact upon the president's reelection. On the other hand, we don't know when the next recession is going to begin.

And I saw that study the other day of economists in which opinion was split whether there might be recession in 2020 or 2021 or not at all...

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROVE: ... in that time frame.

BARTIROMO: So it's all speculation.

ROVE: And so, look, all speculation.

And I saw. It was interesting. The president today said that he wasn't contemplating at this time a cut in the payroll taxes. And yet, since Monday, this has been a sort of storm of attention, oh, the administration is so worried about it, they're considering a payroll tax cut.

Well, the first time we heard it addressed by somebody in the administration was the president, and he said, we're always thinking about tax cuts, but we're not thinking about that tax cut right now.

BARTIROMO: OK. So what about that?

I mean, you don't -- so, in other words, you're saying that this is all more speculation, that there's no tax cuts coming, because that would create more worries over the debt, you know that, if we were to...

ROVE: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: Absolutely.

And it would also -- look, though. With a Democrat House bent upon impeaching the president, let's not kid ourselves.

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROVE: The announcement yesterday by the number four ranking Democrat in the House leadership that he's in favor of impeachment, Jerry Nadler declaring, we don't care whether we have got a resolution of the House empowering us to move forward on our impeachment investigation.

We have a formal impeachment investigation going on -- going right now. Who thinks that a proposal to cut taxes from the administration would get a fair hearing or any hearing in the House of Representatives whatsoever?

So better for the president to think about the things that he can do to help strengthen people's confidence in the economy and administrative actions he can take they will add to our prosperity.

And it would be, in my opinion, a mistake to say, in order to keep us from getting into financial difficulty, in order for us to keep the economy growing, I have got to ask the House of Representatives to do X, because they ain't doing X, whatever it is.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Well, you make a good point, because this is where it really moves into politics, because the truth is, is the subject of unemployment is not a good subject for the Democratic candidates, because we are at a 51-year low in unemployment.

ROVE: No. That's right. Right.

BARTIROMO: Growth is not even a good subject, because we are looking at better than 2 percent growth in the second quarter and 3.1 percent growth in the first quarter.

ROVE: Well, and then wages, because, remember, under the last two years of the Obama administration...

BARTIROMO: And then wages. Good point.

ROVE: Yes, under the last two years of the Obama administration, wages were rising for supervisors more than the working people underneath them.

I think it was about 75 percent more. In the last two years, I think the number is that wages for working people have been rising at a rate 40 percent higher than those for their supervisors.

So we have had the turn in the right direction we want, which is the work and people finally get an increase in their salaries and their wages. And people feel that in the pockets.

That's why I love all this gloom and doom. People say, oh, the economy is slowing up. The economy is turning down. And then we got the July consumer numbers, and what did they say? That the consumers had confidence in -- in the economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: Same with small business. They seem to have confidence in the economy.

So, yes, you can you can talk yourself into a recession. You can claim -- you can claim, yes, we're there and find yourself there.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: But until the American people begin to believe that they have got to somehow sort of shut things down, it ain't going to happen.

BARTIROMO: Well, you know...

ROVE: What was interesting to me was in July that not only were consumers spending, but consumers were saving.

They were looking at what they were getting in the way of increased wages and saying, I want to spend a little bit more to make my wife -- my wife's family -- my family's life better.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: But they also said, we're going to save a little bit more in order to make our family's life better over the long haul.

BARTIROMO: Yes, the savings rate did go up. You're right.

ROVE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, look, I think it's the level of interest rates that has everybody unnerved, because they're so low. What do you want to see the president focus on then going into 2020?

He's a business president, first business president. Do you think he should be focused on economic issues?

ROVE: Well, I think, yes. I think he ought to, because it's the number one issue that people have, the economy.

If the economy is with you, let's be honest, it doesn't help you as much as it hurts you when the economy is going against you. But it's something where the president's job approval on the handling of the economy has consistently been eight, 10, 11, 12 points ahead of his overall job approval.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: So it's a strength.

It's also a point of contrast, because, remember, all of these smart people who are running for president as Democrats said, if we have deregulation, if we have a businessman in charge, if we cut taxes, the economy is going to fall into a deep depression.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: And that didn't happen, all those forecasts of how bad it was going to be if we did what Donald Trump said.

So now Donald Trump is able to say, look what's happened under my -- on my watch.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

ROVE: And look at all these ideas on the other side.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: Look at what they're attempting to do.

Now, the important part is he has to have one other thing -- three things. Here's what I have done. Here's what the other side wants to do. But he's also got to say, here's the next round of things that I want to do to make the prosperity of America stronger and more durable.

BARTIROMO: Yes. He's got to look forward. They want to raise taxes, by the way.

ROVE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, Karl. Thanks so much.

ROVE: Oh, absolutely.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there.

ROVE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Bernie Sanders continuing his Iowa blitz, talking to voters at an ice cream social today, this coming as one of his 2020 rivals is starting to melt in the polls. We have got the scope right after this.

BARTIROMO: Another big day for the Democrats in Iowa, with several 2020 hopefuls making their pitch across the state. Now some new numbers show a bit of a shakeup in the race.

According to a CNN poll released today, former Vice President Joe Biden has increased his lead. He's polling near 30 percent. Meanwhile, Kamala Harris making the biggest move in this poll, and it is not good. She's dropped to 5 percent. That's down from 17.

FOX News's Peter Doocy is blitzing Iowa with the candidates -- Peter.

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Maria, over my right shoulder, you can see the former Vice President Joe Biden speaking for the first time after a few days on vacation and behind closed doors at fund-raisers.

He has a little bit more energy than normal. Maybe that's a result of all the rest from the last couple weeks. But something else that is new for an outdoor event for the former vice president, he is reading off of a teleprompter.

And that does, of course, follow a few days of stories citing anonymous Democratic donors wondering if there is anything that the campaign should be doing differently to avoid some of the gaffes or missteps at the microphone that have caught a lot of attention over the last couple of weeks.

But, regardless, despite all that, Joe Biden does still have that big lead. And his campaign's first commercial in Iowa that dropped today focuses on his position in the polls as paramount to any position on any kind of policy, which puts his approach at odds with the candidate right behind him in that new CNN poll, Bernie Sanders, who almost never breaks from a script where he preaches the value of Medicare for all to play softball, and to show potential caucus-goers the softer side of Bernie Sanders at the field of dreams.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Obviously, this campaign, very different than the last time, is, instead of two candidates yet, we have 23 or so.
