urn:contentItem:5WVX-S291-DXH2-62HD-00000-00San Francisco Problems?; Labor Day Travel; Judge Orders Further Investigation Into Christopher Steele Documents; Tech Giant Antitrust Investigation; Joe Biden Increases Lead In Polls; President Trump Comments On Economy2019-08-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTMark Murphy, Robert Patillo, Emily Larsen, Leeza Garber, Doug Burns, Ned Ryun, Danielle DiMartino Booth, Scott Martin, Lee MunsonNEWSDomestic082001cb.140San Francisco Problems?; Labor Day Travel; Judge Orders Further Investigation Into Christopher Steele Documents; Tech Giant Antitrust Investigation; Joe Biden Increases Lead In Polls; President Trump Comments On EconomyMaria Bartiromo, John Roberts, Karl Rove, Peter Doocy, Lisa Kennedy Montgomery, Claudia Cowan

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Well, amid signs the global economy is slowing, the president is now talking about cutting taxes.

Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Payroll tax is something that we think about. And a lot of people would like to see. And that very much affects the working -- the workers of our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump also taking aim at the Federal Reserve, saying that they have been tardy when it comes to cutting interest rates. He's calling for a full percent cut, maybe not all at once, but over time.

Not helping stocks today. Market closing at the lows right now, down 170 points on the Dow industrials.

Welcome, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo, in today for Neil Cavuto. This is YOUR WORLD.

John Roberts at the White House right now, where it all is going down.

John, good afternoon.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good afternoon to you.

President Trump had a lot to talk about today. We were in the Oval Office for about 30 minutes going over a number of different topics. But first and foremost, of course, was where we are with the economy and where we're headed.

There's an old saying that if you talk your -- talk about recession enough, you can talk your way into one. So the president didn't want to talk about recession. He wanted to talk about things that he believes that he might be able to do, and specifically things that the Fed could do to stop us from going into one.

Listen to what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think the word recession is a word that's inappropriate, because it's just a word that the certain people -- I'm going to be kind.

Certain people and the media are trying to build up, because they'd love to see a recession.

We're very far from a recession. In fact, if the Fed would do its job, I think we would have a tremendous spurt of growth, a tremendous spurt.

The Fed is psychologically very important, less so actually, but very psychologically important. And if the Fed would do it's job, which it's really done poorly over the last year-and-a-half, you would see a burst of growth like you have never seen before.

And that would be lowering interest rates.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: The president very critical of Jerome Powell and what the Fed has been doing, believing that they overshot the mark last year, that they raised interest rates too quickly, too fast -- too quickly, too fast, that would be the same thing -- too high, too quickly.

And he doesn't like their program of quantitative tightening. So the president is calling -- called again day in the Oval Office for a cut in the Fed Funds Rate of 100 basis points. That would be a full percentage rate cut, which would take it down to the area of about 1 percent.

The president said, now, not all at once. But then he would also like to see some quantitative easing as well, which we saw during the Obama administration.

Another thing that the president is thinking about, Maria, is indexing capital gains. It's very popular among a lot of people who tend to be wealthy who have a lot of investments in the market, and also considering another potential cut to the payroll tax.

This happened in 2011 and 2012 as part of the economic stimulus in the Obama administration. And that is a tax cut that really affects the middle class, because you cap out at about $95,000. And people who make more than that per year don't get the tax cut. So the tax cut goes to people between about $30,000 and $95,000, which is squarely in the middle class.

Listen to what the president said about that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Payroll taxes, I have been thinking about payroll taxes for a long time. Whether or not we do it now or not is -- it's not being done because of recession, because we are -- legitimately, if we had a cut in interest rates by the Fed, if they would do their job properly, and if they would do a meaningful cut, because they raised too fast, you would see growth like you have not seen ever in this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: You're probably detecting a them there. Even though the president was talking about tax cuts, he came back to the idea of the Fed needing to cut rates and needing to inject some more money into the system as well to keep the economy humming along.

China, Maria, is also a big piece of this. The president again said today that he is not yet ready to cut a deal with China. And he said whether or not there is short-term pain because of his negotiations with China and his policy of tariffs against China to try to bring them to the table is irrelevant.

He says we might need some short-term pain because long term if we don't do something about China, it's going to be catastrophic, because they will eat our lunch five to 10 years from now -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Well, they have said that's where they want to go.

John, thank you so much.

So is a big rate cut and a middle-class tax cut what's needed to keep this economy moving forward?

Let's bring in former Dallas Federal Reserve adviser Danielle DiMartino Booth and market watchers Scott Martin and Lee Munson.

Great to see everybody this morning.

Danielle, let me kick it off with you. Your reaction to a full cut by the Federal Reserve and potentially a cut in payroll taxes?

DANIELLE DIMARTINO BOOTH, FORMER FEDERAL RESERVE ADVISER: Well, it looks like the president is hoping that the country can go out there double- barreled and answer what the European Central Bank, what the Europeans have been promised, which is basically rate cuts and quantitative easing.

He wants to put some fiscal stimulus on top of that that really targets the middle class, and then capital gains tax cuts as well to hold the stock market together. So it really does seem like a perfect Goldilocks scenario, if he was able to wave a magic wand and make this happen overnight.

I don't know how willing Jay Powell and his peers are going to be to launch that type of a shock and awe campaign that was really emblematic of some of the -- some of the crisis years, when the economy was truly in much more than a recession.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Scott Martin, how do you see it?

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Well, it's funny.

I mean, talking about '07, and I remember that fall very well. I got married that fall. And other than that event, it was a really bad fall, because, to Danielle's point, the Fed was cutting rates faster than we could even see them being cut.

And it didn't help. We went into a major financial crisis. And that's what I think worries me here with the Fed on the other side now, as the Trump -- as the president has pointed out, is that they raised too fast. I think they have been too hawkish.

Even when we got the cut recently at the end of July, Maria, says, well, this is a mid-cycle adjustment, don't get used to this, we're not going to be this nice.

So it still -- it still to me boggles my mind that you have the 30-year government bond, my friends a skosh over 2 percent. The Fed Funds' overnight target rate at 2.25 percent, that tells you it's too high.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: They need to listen to the markets, not the president, and cut some more.

BARTIROMO: Yes, look at the 10-year, where that is. I mean, it's just extraordinary, what you're -- what we're looking at here, Lee Munson.

Your reaction. Do you want to see a cut?

LEE MUNSON, PORTFOLIO WEALTH ADVISORS: I want to see a cut. And I will tell you why.

I mean, you ask a lot of bond traders right now, they already think that we're going to see three cuts, maybe 75 basis points, before the end of the year. So the president's not that far off. Number two, I think this is going to be something that's going to help farmers.

I mean, I'm in New Mexico. You go down to Southern New Mexico, and you see land fallow right now. It's going to help drillers in the energy sector that are overleveraged and can use it. And you have also got to look at local regional banks. They need this right now.

What people don't understand Maria is that we have with China intertwined trade and national security issues. I do a lot of business with people in national defense. We have got to deal with this Chinese thing. And the president says he will push this economy into recession to deal with that.

Unlike the Russians, unlike the Soviets, money talks with China, and so I think that we're going to have the guns-and-butter approach. We got to juice this system for the next 12 months so that Trump can get these issues with China worked out.

Again, I'm fiscally conservative, but we have got to address the intellectual property, thievery, the military espionage, Huawei, all that stuff.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

MARTIN: All the things they won't agree on.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: These are all the things that they reneged on.

So -- and, by the way, let's not forget that China has broken its promises so many times in so many different situations, whether it's the WTO, or breaking promises with Hong Kong. Look with the two million people in the streets as we speak. Breaking promises with the U.S., saying that they're going to buy beef, and then they don't.

So even if we were to see a deal, will it be enforceable?

DIMARTINO BOOTH: Well, I think that, Maria, that's fantastic question, because we have seen them renege and go back on their word time and again.

BARTIROMO: Right.

DIMARTINO BOOTH: We have seen the way that they're treating the people in Hong Kong. They're simply not a trustworthy negotiating partner.

And I think that there's every reason to question the integrity of China's intentions at this juncture. What I'm not sure about is whether or not tariffs are the correct instrument anymore. And I think that President Trump has seen that and he pulled back on those September the 1st increased tariffs for that very reason.

And now he's looking for a different way to go about providing relief to this economy, so that it can get through, so that his administration can get through these very tough negotiations.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, the issue is that the economy feels good.

But, at the end of the day, we are seeing a bit of a slowdown. We know that Europe is having a hard time generating any growth.

So what about that, Scott? Do you feel things are poised to slow down considerably by year-end?

MARTIN: I don't know about considerably. I think the slowdown has already begun.

I mean, I think -- you mentioned it. It's overseas. It's definitely in the U.S. The housing market, I know homebuilder sentiment is good, but housing prices, from my eye, in certain areas that have been good have slowed down.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: Home buyer sentiment has kind of cooled off. We have seen business sentiment waver a bit. Consumer sentiment recently fell off some highs.

So I think a slowdown is imminent, if not here already, Maria. But, yes, it's not a major slowdown, but one that needs to be helped along a little bit.

BARTIROMO: Lee Munson, real quick, would you buy into this sell-off or stay on the sidelines here?

MUNSON: Buy in the sell-off. Buy what's beaten up.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MUNSON: We have got 12 more months. And I think the next six months, you buy every dip that you have, and then you start getting concerned. But between now and the end of the year, I think you have to be bold and then - - then I start to get more panicky and freaked out.

BARTIROMO: All right, thank you so much to the panel. Great conversation there.

History says, if the economy is good, there is a good chance that the incumbent president gets four more years. So do some new economic jitters have the White House feeling jittery itself?

We will talk to Karl Rove when we come right back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We heard earlier President Trump saying that some of the media are talking down the economy ahead of the 2020 election.

Want to get that read on the -- on that with the former White House deputy chief of staff for President George W. Bush, Karl Rove.

Karl, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thank you for being here.

KARL ROVE, FORMER SENIOR ADVISER TO PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: And there is something to say about that, that you could talk yourself into a recession, right? How do you see it?

ROVE: Yes, look, it's interesting how the narrative changes.

I mean, we have the economy is going really great, and now doubts about where Europe is or doubts about where the world is suddenly become a tempest of conversation in the media about the recession happening before the 2020 election and this affecting the president's reelection chances.

If a recession were to happen, and it were to happen before the 2020 election, sure kit would have an impact upon the president's reelection. On the other hand, we don't know when the next recession is going to begin.

And I saw that study the other day of economists in which opinion was split whether there might be recession in 2020 or 2021 or not at all...

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROVE: ... in that time frame.

BARTIROMO: So it's all speculation.

ROVE: And so, look, all speculation.

And I saw. It was interesting. The president today said that he wasn't contemplating at this time a cut in the payroll taxes. And yet, since Monday, this has been a sort of storm of attention, oh, the administration is so worried about it, they're considering a payroll tax cut.

Well, the first time we heard it addressed by somebody in the administration was the president, and he said, we're always thinking about tax cuts, but we're not thinking about that tax cut right now.

BARTIROMO: OK. So what about that?

I mean, you don't -- so, in other words, you're saying that this is all more speculation, that there's no tax cuts coming, because that would create more worries over the debt, you know that, if we were to...

ROVE: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: Absolutely.

And it would also -- look, though. With a Democrat House bent upon impeaching the president, let's not kid ourselves.

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROVE: The announcement yesterday by the number four ranking Democrat in the House leadership that he's in favor of impeachment, Jerry Nadler declaring, we don't care whether we have got a resolution of the House empowering us to move forward on our impeachment investigation.

We have a formal impeachment investigation going on -- going right now. Who thinks that a proposal to cut taxes from the administration would get a fair hearing or any hearing in the House of Representatives whatsoever?

So better for the president to think about the things that he can do to help strengthen people's confidence in the economy and administrative actions he can take they will add to our prosperity.

And it would be, in my opinion, a mistake to say, in order to keep us from getting into financial difficulty, in order for us to keep the economy growing, I have got to ask the House of Representatives to do X, because they ain't doing X, whatever it is.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Well, you make a good point, because this is where it really moves into politics, because the truth is, is the subject of unemployment is not a good subject for the Democratic candidates, because we are at a 51-year low in unemployment.

ROVE: No. That's right. Right.

BARTIROMO: Growth is not even a good subject, because we are looking at better than 2 percent growth in the second quarter and 3.1 percent growth in the first quarter.

ROVE: Well, and then wages, because, remember, under the last two years of the Obama administration...

BARTIROMO: And then wages. Good point.

ROVE: Yes, under the last two years of the Obama administration, wages were rising for supervisors more than the working people underneath them.

I think it was about 75 percent more. In the last two years, I think the number is that wages for working people have been rising at a rate 40 percent higher than those for their supervisors.

So we have had the turn in the right direction we want, which is the work and people finally get an increase in their salaries and their wages. And people feel that in the pockets.

That's why I love all this gloom and doom. People say, oh, the economy is slowing up. The economy is turning down. And then we got the July consumer numbers, and what did they say? That the consumers had confidence in -- in the economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: Same with small business. They seem to have confidence in the economy.

So, yes, you can you can talk yourself into a recession. You can claim -- you can claim, yes, we're there and find yourself there.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: But until the American people begin to believe that they have got to somehow sort of shut things down, it ain't going to happen.

BARTIROMO: Well, you know...

ROVE: What was interesting to me was in July that not only were consumers spending, but consumers were saving.

They were looking at what they were getting in the way of increased wages and saying, I want to spend a little bit more to make my wife -- my wife's family -- my family's life better.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: But they also said, we're going to save a little bit more in order to make our family's life better over the long haul.

BARTIROMO: Yes, the savings rate did go up. You're right.

ROVE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, look, I think it's the level of interest rates that has everybody unnerved, because they're so low. What do you want to see the president focus on then going into 2020?

He's a business president, first business president. Do you think he should be focused on economic issues?

ROVE: Well, I think, yes. I think he ought to, because it's the number one issue that people have, the economy.

If the economy is with you, let's be honest, it doesn't help you as much as it hurts you when the economy is going against you. But it's something where the president's job approval on the handling of the economy has consistently been eight, 10, 11, 12 points ahead of his overall job approval.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: So it's a strength.

It's also a point of contrast, because, remember, all of these smart people who are running for president as Democrats said, if we have deregulation, if we have a businessman in charge, if we cut taxes, the economy is going to fall into a deep depression.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: And that didn't happen, all those forecasts of how bad it was going to be if we did what Donald Trump said.

So now Donald Trump is able to say, look what's happened under my -- on my watch.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

ROVE: And look at all these ideas on the other side.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: Look at what they're attempting to do.

Now, the important part is he has to have one other thing -- three things. Here's what I have done. Here's what the other side wants to do. But he's also got to say, here's the next round of things that I want to do to make the prosperity of America stronger and more durable.

BARTIROMO: Yes. He's got to look forward. They want to raise taxes, by the way.

ROVE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, Karl. Thanks so much.

ROVE: Oh, absolutely.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there.

ROVE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Bernie Sanders continuing his Iowa blitz, talking to voters at an ice cream social today, this coming as one of his 2020 rivals is starting to melt in the polls. We have got the scope right after this.

BARTIROMO: Another big day for the Democrats in Iowa, with several 2020 hopefuls making their pitch across the state. Now some new numbers show a bit of a shakeup in the race.

According to a CNN poll released today, former Vice President Joe Biden has increased his lead. He's polling near 30 percent. Meanwhile, Kamala Harris making the biggest move in this poll, and it is not good. She's dropped to 5 percent. That's down from 17.

FOX News's Peter Doocy is blitzing Iowa with the candidates -- Peter.

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Maria, over my right shoulder, you can see the former Vice President Joe Biden speaking for the first time after a few days on vacation and behind closed doors at fund-raisers.

He has a little bit more energy than normal. Maybe that's a result of all the rest from the last couple weeks. But something else that is new for an outdoor event for the former vice president, he is reading off of a teleprompter.

And that does, of course, follow a few days of stories citing anonymous Democratic donors wondering if there is anything that the campaign should be doing differently to avoid some of the gaffes or missteps at the microphone that have caught a lot of attention over the last couple of weeks.

But, regardless, despite all that, Joe Biden does still have that big lead. And his campaign's first commercial in Iowa that dropped today focuses on his position in the polls as paramount to any position on any kind of policy, which puts his approach at odds with the candidate right behind him in that new CNN poll, Bernie Sanders, who almost never breaks from a script where he preaches the value of Medicare for all to play softball, and to show potential caucus-goers the softer side of Bernie Sanders at the field of dreams.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Obviously, this campaign, very different than the last time, is, instead of two candidates yet, we have 23 or so.

So no one's going to get 50 percent. I think it's going to be a fight to get 25, 30 percent. But I think we're in that fight.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOOCY: And I was just inside on this deck where Joe Biden is speaking.

It's worth pointing out, as we try to figure out which candidates are generating the most excitement in early states like Iowa, it's a smaller venue, and there are a lot of empty seats in the back -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

All right, Peter, thank you.

urn:contentItem:5T0C-BWT1-F03R-N3TY-00000-00San Francisco's Protectionist Attempt to Ban Company Cafeterias2018-08-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisSan Francisco's Protectionist Attempt to Ban Company CafeteriasBrittany Hunter

Aug 08, 2018( Foundation for Economic Education: https://fee.org Delivered by Newstex) Silicon Valley is no stranger to competition. The race to produce cutting-edge tech products that set you apart from the crowd is never-ending in a sector that is constantly upgrading. And in order to dominate the market, you have to be the best. But in addition to the market pressure tech companies face when it comes to the actual products, each brand is also vying to employ the best talent.

One of the most common perks provided by tech giants is onsite cafeterias where quality food is provided to employees at no extra cost. In the hunt for talented employees, both big tech companies and smaller startups have offered perks to sweeten the deal for potential employees. Google famously provided nap pods for its employees while other tech giants have offered onsite massages and doctors in order to look more appealing for job seekers. One of the most common perks provided by tech giants is onsite cafeterias where quality food is provided to employees at no extra cost. In addition to increasing productivity by incentivizing employees to stay onsite and take shorter lunches, offering free food also provides relief to employees. And since Silicon Valley is not known for its low cost of living, free food is a real draw for potential employees. If they were going to have to pay astronomical costs to live in the city— sometimes as high as $3,400 a month for a one-bedroom apartment—then at least they could save a few bucks by eating lunch for free. This in-kind payment may be cheaper to provide than you'd think since the company might be able to get better deals on the food than individuals, since they're buying in bulk. Feeding one's workers also fosters a familial atmosphere that may increase worker loyalty. The new measure is more about protectionism and government control than anything else. But the era of employee cafeterias may soon be coming to an end thanks to two San Francisco city officials. City supervisors Ahsha Safa and Aaron Peskin recently proposed new regulations that would make onsite cafeterias illegal. If passed, the measure will ban the construction of employee cafeterias in new buildings, but existing cafeterias will be allowed to stay. Banning cafeterias in private buildings seems like an absurd quest to take on. But the new measure is more about protectionism and government control than anything else.When 'Buy Local' becomes a WeaponIn 2011, tech companies were given a payroll tax break in exchange for moving into Mid-Market, a rough area in San Francisco near City Hall. The city had hoped that if these tech companies to move into the neighborhood, they would bring jobs and commerce with them. But this plan has not unfolded quite like city officials had planned. While the tech companies themselves are doing just fine, other local businesses are struggling to keep their doors open. Many restaurants, in particular, had to close due to an inability to draw in customers. Of course, the restaurateurs were naturally frustrated but they chose to blame their low sales on the tech companies. Gwyneth Borden, executive director of the Golden Gate Restaurant Association, supported the cafeteria ban. They reasoned that since some of these companies provide cafeterias, employees were choosing to stay on site to purchase food or snacks, rather than going to a nearby restaurant or cafe. Gwyneth Borden, executive director of the Golden Gate Restaurant Association, supported the cafeteria ban saying, 'you can't compete with free.' And while it is surely more convenient to blame other people than it is to reevaluate your business plan, there are many other factors to consider when looking at this struggling neighborhood. San Francisco is infamous for being disgusting. In addition to seeing people defecate in the street, it is not uncommon to see used needles and hard drug use taking place right outside of the buildings that are currently home to Square, Twitter, and Uber. In fact, each of these buildings is heavily secured in order to keep the craziness of the streets at bay. Recently, one store owner in this neighborhood had to kick someone out of his store for taking his pants off. That same person later came back to urinate on the store's window. However, this same business owner has also been shocked that his store isn't thriving when clearly, there are other issues far more problematic than free cafeterias. The presence of these tech companies cannot magically clean up the streets of San Francisco. The presence of these tech companies cannot magically clean up the streets of San Francisco. But city officials are acting as though Square, Twitter, and Uber have somehow failing to live up to the terms of the tax break by failing to transform the city. But the only thing required of these companies in order to receive the tax break was to move into Mid-Market, which they have. Peskin, one of the architects of the new ban, tried to blame the tech industry and their lack of community for the continued degradation of the neighborhood saying:'We don't want employees biking or driving into their office, staying there all day long and going home. This is about getting people out of their office, interacting with the community and adding to the vibrancy of the community.'But unfortunately for Peskin, city officials do not have the authority to dictate its residents behavior, especially when it comes to commerce. James Manning, the director of user experience at Dolby Laboratories commented on the new measure to ban employee cafeterias:'I'm not in favor of local government mandating where I can and cannot eat. The idea the food doesn't need to be subsidized, that tech workers make so much, is a fallacy. Tech workers, the vast majority, with the cost of living here, are not wealthy.'To be sure, when Manning speaks of subsidies, he speaks of them in a private fashion. To call these lunches 'free' would be misleading, as they are subsidized by the companies and are a type of employee benefit. Choosing to offer free food to your employee is something you are doing at your own cost as a means of compensation for your employees. If, like many already do, a tech company chooses to offer onsite doctors to its employees, the government wouldn't tell them to stop this practice because the neighborhood doctors were missing out on patients. And yet, this type of regulatory chaos is exactly what is happening with the cafeterias. But as with most regulations, when you dig deeper you uncover the underlying motivation: protectionism from others refusing to compete.Protectionism from All AnglesCompetition is tough. No one has ever said anything to the contrary. And when you have sacrificed your life savings to get a business off the ground only to see it fail, it is absolutely understandable for someone to be angry. But blaming others does little to remedy the problem. The same can be said for trying to legislate individual behavior in order to rig the competition; it is never justified and always wrong. But this is exactly what some of the neighboring businesses are doing. Setting up shop in the Mid-Market neighborhood was a risk from the get go. After all, the homelessness and prevalent drug abuse had been there long before the new tech companies moved into town. Each entrepreneur knew this before opening their doors, but they relied on companies like Square and Twitter to hand them customers on a platter, rather than work for them. The food being offered at these 'off campus' restaurants was not enough to compete with the free lunch offered on site. Unfortunately, the food being offered at these 'off campus' restaurants was not enough to compete with the free lunch offered on site and it was certainly not enough to coax these employees out onto the dangerous streets. But this does not justify the creation of new laws. To make matters worse for the tech companies, they are dealing with protectionism from all angles. Not only are restaurant owners angry, but other tech companies are seeing this proposed regulation as a chance to compete for talent. 'This could even the playing field a bit,' Paul Rava, the chief financial officer at Credit Sesame said. Credit Sesame is a startup that provides free credit scores and does not provide a cafeteria to its employees. Rava believes that by implementing this ban, his company along with others like Salesforce, which also does not have a cafeteria, will stand a better chance at attracting potential employees. Just like the restaurant owners, neighboring tech companies are also trying to use the government to shield themselves from competition.Protectionists Gonna ProtectThe new restrictions are not set to be voted on until the fall at the earliest. One can only hope that common sense prevails in the meantime. Market competition is about a lot more than just the product you offer. Companies with great products, or great food, have often failed because their marketing strategy didn't work, and this can also include choosing to open a business in a rough neighborhood. Location matters, especially for a restaurant, and if the neighborhood does not provide you with the sales you are looking for, you can choose to either take the risk and be ready to deal with the consequences, or move somewhere else. But resorting to protectionism in order to control the opposition is wrong. Period.

urn:contentItem:5YR7-6NR1-JCMN-Y1YH-00000-00San Fransisco's Emergency Rules Threaten Food Deliveries2020-04-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:32ZLexisNexisSan Fransisco's Emergency Rules Threaten Food DeliveriesSteven Greenhut

Apr 22, 2020( Fox & Hounds: http://www.foxandhoundsdaily.com/ Delivered by Newstex) San Francisco officials have imposed one of the tightest lockdowns[1] in the country, which has made residents of the nation's second-highest density city increasingly dependent on deliveries from grocery stores and restaurants. If officials there want people to stay home and avoid interacting with others at the checkout lines, they should do everything they can to encourage these kinds of services. Instead, Mayor London Breed on Friday issued an emergency edict[2] that will discourage home deliveries and will likely boost prices - and reduce choices - for consumers. The order, announced with support from the Board of Supervisors[3], caps all commission fees that home-delivery apps charge to restaurants at 15 percent.

The caps stay in place until restaurants are allowed to offer dine-in service again. These companies sometimes charge as much as 30 percent, but often charge as little as 10 percent. Everyone is sympathetic to the plight of restaurants during these trying times. In San Francisco, restaurant owners have complained about low profit margins after they pay the firms that delivery the meals to people's homes. But whenever government caps the price of a product or service, the end result always is the same: shortages[4]. 'If the city attempts to dictate contract terms between delivery services and restaurants, it would force our services to radically alter our businesses just as we desperately try to meet the needs of restaurants, delivery people, customers and our communities,' according to an April 8 letter[5] to San Francisco officials from four companies that provide deliveries (DoorDash, Grubhub, Postmates and Uber Eats). The commission caps, the letter explains[6], would increase fees for consumers, thus putting home deliveries 'out of reach for all but the city's most prosperous residents.' Furthermore, they not only provide needed food for the city's residents, but have been a lifeline for vulnerable populations such as the elderly and immunocompromised. Delivery apps also provide an ongoing source of income for drivers and restaurants - no small thing during these tough economic times. Despite the tired criticisms[7] of those who complain that these companies are flourishing during the crisis, the reality is much different. According to the letter, DoorDash has slashed fees[8] charged to independent restaurants by 50 percent. Grubhub has provided $30 million in aid to restaurants. Uber Eats waived customer fees for orders from small restaurants. Postmates has waived commissions for new brick-and-mortar retail merchants in San Francisco. These are just a few of the ways that these app-based companies - like many companies[9] in myriad industries - have creatively confronted the COVID-19 challenge. It's best to let voluntary relationships sort themselves out, rather than allow government to impose heavy-handed and counterproductive regulations. All companies need the flexibility to determine their own price structures and run their businesses as they know best. App-based delivery companies rightly are concerned that San Francisco's emergency order will be mimicked elsewhere. Officials in Chicago and New York, for instance, already have discussed similar measures[10]. Some people worry that it might be hard to get rid of the cumbersome new rules even after the crisis passes. San Francisco's edict was supported by the local restaurant lobby[11] which, presumably, would see the foolishness of price controls if the city capped restaurant profits to protect struggling homebound residents. Ironically, many restaurants could suffer the most from the caps, given that they could depress demand for deliveries and, as Restaurant Dive noted[12], 'force delivery companies to stop doing business with lower-cost restaurants.' One of the reasons Americans have survived the economic clampdown as well as they have is because of our market-based system[13] that allows prices to free to rise and fall based on supply and demand. This is how markets work every day, even if we don't like when some things cost more than we'd prefer to pay. Whenever governments mess with that process, customers can't get what they need - or have to wait in line or do without. Instead of waiting to see the easily predictable consequences[14] of the edict, the city should roll back the regulations and let restaurants and app-based delivery companies work out their own arrangements. San Franciscans need food-delivery services now more than ever, so it would be tragic if the city made it harder for residents to access them.
